descriptionSet.description: A sample image in the catalogue of Empire Calender Manufacturing Co. showing scenes of village life like farming: A man cultivating rice with an oxplough, women using a water pump to secure their water supply etc. In the background, the sea and a ship can be seen. On the left lower corner of the image, the manufacturer's signet ECM co is depicted.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

rights.text: Copyrighted. Copyright with the original artists and publishers.

hra:item.hra:value: description-en: A sample image in the catalogue of Empire Calender Manufacturing Co. showing scenes of village life like farming: A man cultivating rice with an oxplough, women using a water pump to secure their water supply etc. In the background, the sea and a ship can be seen. On the left lower corner of the image, the manufacturer's signet ECM co is depicted. (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: This image provides an important, complementary revelation about setting and subject matter, both this time from the Nehruvian third ‘moment’ but in sharp contrast to the second moment in theme. When the Paul collection is viewed in its entirety, one of the striking differences between the second and third ‘moments’ of image-production, is the re-incorporation of rural life in constructions of the everyday. Where this had featured – at least as an ethnographic location in British-produced labels of the first moment – it is much reduced as a place in the imaginings of the nationalist period. Instead, we are taken inside, to interiors as abstractly domestic and middle-class as they are modern and implicitly urban. In the third period of production, even the rural can be modern and so can be reincorporated as an imagined and desired locale of the everyday. Indeed, in the independent Nehruvian India, agriculture is explicitly recognized as an essential, even key, contributor to the nation’s well-being. (Sandria B. Freitag)(gs)
related literature: Braudel, Fernand 1981. "The Structures of Everyday Life". London: Collins. (gs)
related literature: de Certeau, Michel 1984. "The Practices of Everyday Life" . Berkeley: University of California Press. (gs)

related literature: Ramaswamy, Sumathi 2002. "Visualising India's geo-body: Globes, maps, bodyscapes". In: Contributions to Indian Sociology 36 (2002): 151 - 189. (gs)
